Bettercare • Bettercare books • Newborn Care • Test

Test 6: Feeding sick or high-risk infants

  1. Which of the following is found in the cells of the body?
    1. Intravascular fluid
    2. Intercellular fluid
    3. Intracellular fluid correct
    4. Serum
  2. The fluid volume needed by a term infant on day 1 is:
    1. 25 ml/kg
    2. 60 ml/kg correct
    3. 100 ml/kg
    4. 150 ml/kg
  3. What volume of fluid is needed by most infants after day 4?
    1. 60 ml/kg
    2. 100 ml/kg
    3. 150 ml/kg correct
    4. 200 ml/kg
  4. Infants need less fluid on the first few days of life because:
    1. They weigh less.
    2. They do not suck well.
    3. Their stools consist of meconium.
    4. Their kidneys only produce a little urine. correct
  5. The fluid volume needed on day 1 for infants that weigh less than 1500 g at birth?is:
    1. 25 ml/kg
    2. 60 ml/kg
    3. 75 ml/kg correct
    4. 100 ml/kg
  6. Which infants should be given an extra 25?ml/kg fluid per day?
    1. Infants under an overhead radiant heater correct
    2. Infants in a closed incubator
    3. Infants receiving phototherapy
    4. Infants weighing more than 4000 g
  7. The following can be used as resuscitation fluid because it is isotonic with blood (i.e. contains the same concentration of sodium):
    1. Half-strength Darrow’s
    2. 10% dextrose
    3. Normal saline correct
    4. Neonatalyte
  8. Which of the following can be used as maintenance fluid?
    1. Ringer’s lactate
    2. Neonatalyte correct
    3. Plasmalyte B
    4. Half-normal saline
  9. The best milk for preterm infants is:
    1. A soya bean formula
    2. Special preterm formula
    3. Breast milk correct
    4. Standard infant formula
  10. A preterm infant born after a 30 week gestation should be able to suck and take its feed by mouth when it is:
    1. 1 weeks old
    2. 2 weeks old
    3. 6 weeks old correct
    4. 8 weeks old
  11. An infant below 1500 g should be fed:
    1. Every 2 hours correct
    2. Every 3 hours
    3. Every 4 hours
    4. Every 8 hours
  12. An infant between 1500 and 1800?g should be fed:
    1. 12 times a day
    2. 8 times a day correct
    3. 6 times a day
    4. On demand
  13. Small milk feeds can usually be started in sick infants when:
    1. They are 48 hours old.
    2. They pass meconium.
    3. They no longer need extra oxygen.
    4. They are clinically improving. correct
  14. Intravenous fluids should be given on day 1 to:
    1. Infants weighing less than 1500 g correct
    2. Infants weighing less than 2000 g
    3. All preterm infants
    4. All low birth weight infants
  15. What is the danger of giving nasogastric feeds to a sick infant?
    1. Hypoglycaemia
    2. Vomiting correct
    3. Loose stools
    4. Pyrexia
  16. Term infants that are underweight for gestational age or wasted should:
    1. Not be fed for the first 6 hours.
    2. Be given a milk feed within an hour of delivery. correct
    3. Be given 10% dextrose feeds via a nasogastric tube.
    4. Be given intravenous fluids.
  17. What supplements should a preterm infant receive?
    1. Ferrodrops 1 ml daily from day 7
    2. Ferrodrops 0.6 ml each day starting when the infant begins to suck
    3. Multivitamin drops 0.3 ml daily from day 5 correct
    4. Multivitamin drops 0.1 ml with each feed
  18. What should you do if an infant has bile-stained (green) vomiting?
    1. Wash out the stomach with 2% sodium bicarbonate.
    2. Decrease the volume of the feeds.
    3. Feed the infant more frequently.
    4. Refer the infant to a level 2 or 3 hospital. correct
  19. What is a common cause of vomiting in preterm infants?
    1. Gastro-oesophageal reflux correct
    2. Failure to pass meconium
    3. Breast milk feeds
    4. Feeds given every 2 hours
  20. Vomiting in many infants can be prevented by:
    1. Increasing the volume of the feeds
    2. Nursing the infant on its back
    3. Stopping the multivitamin drops
    4. Raising the head of the mattress correct
